Notes: Preschools, primary schools, secondary schools, and universities are permitted to hold in-person classes.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210510001719/https://ao.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Health centers and hospitals are fully operational. Restaurants are open from 6:00 a.m. to 8:00 p.m. for table service, and from 6:00 a.m. to 10:00 p.m. for takeout.? In person dining is limited to 50 percent capacity with no more than four guests per table.?Stores, including supermarkets, can remain open until 8p.m . Recreational use of beaches and public swimming pools remains suspended    https://web.archive.org/web/20210510001719/https://ao.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Museums and monuments, movie theaters, cultural and art fairs, libraries, and media centers are open but limited to 50 percent capacity. Religious activities are limited to four days a week with no more than 50 percent capacity or 150 people and are limited to a maximum duration of 2 hours if held in enclosed spaces.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210510001719/https://ao.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

House gatherings up to a maximum of 15 people are allowed. Festive gatherings are not allowed in a non-domiciliary place, and access to party halls and similar establishments is prohibited.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210510030528/http://www.embaixadadeangola.pt/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/DI%C3%81RIO-DA-REP%C3%9ABLICA.-28.04.21.pdf
Public transportation is limited to 75 percent capacity.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210510001719/https://ao.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

The Angolan government recommends staying indoors and away from public areas between the hours of 10p.m. and 5a.m.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210510001719/https://ao.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

The sanitary fence is maintained in the Province of Luanda. A negative COVID-19 test is required for entrances and exits of Luanda territory.    Domestic flights require a serological test with a negative result, made in the 72 hours prior to the trip.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210510030528/http://www.embaixadadeangola.pt/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/DI%C3%81RIO-DA-REP%C3%9ABLICA.-28.04.21.pdf

International flights have resumed in a limited capacity. Flights to or from Brazil, Australia, Nigeria and the United Kingdom have been suspended as of December 26, 2020.?    The Angolan government has instituted mandatory home quarantine for anyone entering the country, regardless of citizenship. Government regulations require arriving passengers to re-test seven days after arrival and be released by the health authorities in order to leave quarantine.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210510001719/https://ao.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210510030528/http://www.embaixadadeangola.pt/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/DI%C3%81RIO-DA-REP%C3%9ABLICA.-28.04.21.pdf
The COVID-19 information website is updated daily  https://web.archive.org/web/20210510040342/https://www.cisp.gov.ao:10443/en/

Testing is required for all domestic & international flights, entrances and exits of provinces with health fences.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210510030528/http://www.embaixadadeangola.pt/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/DI%C3%81RIO-DA-REP%C3%9ABLICA.-28.04.21.pdf

The use of a face mask is required in all public areas, including anytime you leave your house or hotel room, while using public transport, and in all establishments. Face masks are not required if you are operating a vehicle alone or exercising outside.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210510001719/https://ao.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Vaccines are available for health professionals, defense and security personnel, teachers, citizens over 65, patients over 18 with commodities.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210510035521/https://governo.gov.ao/ao/noticias/covid-19-2-2-2-2-2-2-2/

Persons aged 60 or over are exempted from in-person work in a public or private entity. However, by agreement between the employer and the employee, schemes may be created to allow the performance of face-to-face work in safe conditions.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210510030528/http://www.embaixadadeangola.pt/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/DI%C3%81RIO-DA-REP%C3%9ABLICA.-28.04.21.pdf

Melchior Ndadaye International Airport (BJM) is open, and all incoming and outgoing passengers must possess negative results from a COVID-19 test taken within 72 hours prior to travel. Travelers arriving in Burundi by air must quarantine for seven days. All travelers must take a test on arrival in Burundi and a second test after six days in isolation. Travelers will be isolated at facilities approved by authorities and will be transported to and from these sites by security forces. Any traveler who tests positive will be placed into quarantine for 14 days at a government-designated hotel, along with all persons traveling in their party.    web.archive.org/save/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/464946/burundi-covid-19-related-restrictions-in-place-nationwide-remain-largely-unchanged-as-of-april-8-update-10#:~:text=Travelers%20arriving%20in%20Burundi%20by,these%20sites%20by%20security%20forces.

Land and sea borders remain closed, but international commercial flights to Burkina Faso are allowed to operate in a limited capacity. All travelers arriving in Burkina Faso must provide evidence of a negative result from a COVID-19 test taken no more than five days before arrival. Travelers without such documentation must submit to a test at the port of entry and face up to 14 days of quarantine at home or in a hotel of choice, if the result is positive. Authorities also perform temperature checks at airports.     Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210510090023/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/462931/burkina-faso-covid-19-restrictions-remain-unchanged-nationwide-as-of-april-2-update-13    https://web.archive.org/web/20210510090055/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/burkina-faso/entry-requirements

Government of Botswana announced assistance for businesses regarding covid-19. For instance, to give businesses some cash-flow relief the Government will do the following:    -Guarantee loans by commercial banks to businesses mostly affected by COVID-19  -Give eligible businesses affected by COVID-19 access to credit to support ongoing operations in conditions where credit becomes more difficult to obtain  -Give tax concessions to businesses in eligible sectors.  -Banks have agreed to offer restructuring of loan facilities through which each bank will consider each case within their credit policy and parameters. This will include owner-occupied residential property mortgages and motor vehicle loans.  -All commercial banks will offer a payment holiday for three months with the option to extend to six months to the affected sectors.  -Regular payment obligations including life insurance premium payment, retirement fund contributions and loan installments will be restructured and rescheduled to offer relief for at least three months to COVID-19 affected people subject to individual policies.    web.archive.org/save/https://www.gov.bw/assistance-businesses
No changes.      web.archive.org/save/https://www.gov.bw/assistance-businesses

The following provinces have a curfew in place from 10:00 pm to 4:00 am: Kinshasa, North Kivu, South Kivu, Kongo Central, Lualaba, Haut-Katanga. As of April 13, the curfew is lifted entirely in all other provinces.  Compulsory wearing of masks and social distancing is required when outside.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210524160531/https://cd.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Travellers moving from one province to another must present a negative coronavirus test result. The test result date must fall within 3 days before the date you intend to leave the province. https://web.archive.org/web/20210503174650/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/democratic-republic-of-the-congo/coronavirus

No policy changes. Continues to be a 2G score since the upgrade to “state of calamity” entails more restrictions in opening hours and maximum capacity.     “With the exception of Brava Island, the entire national territory is in a state of calamity for 30 days, with fortnightly or weekly assessments of the situation. The state of calamity implies more restrictive measures in terms of opening hours for commercial establishments, restaurants and bars, but also in terms of activities of a cultural or political nature with a maximum capacity that cannot exceed 150 people”.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210502112157/https://covid19.cv/governo-decreta-estado-de-calamidade-publica/

No changes in the value. The new “state of calamity” requires both public and private parties to be banned.    “According to the Head of Government, the calamity situation will imply some more restrictive measures regarding the opening hours of commercial establishments, restaurants, and bars; at the level of cultural or political activities with a maximum capacity that cannot exceed 150 people […] Both public and private parties are banned. Only intra-family parties are allowed.”  https://web.archive.org/web/20210502114936/https://expressodasilhas.cv/pais/2021/04/30/covid-19-governo-declara-estado-de-calamidade/74569

In the “state of calamity” only intra-family parties are allowed (which is assumed to fall under the limit of 10 people).    “According to the Head of Government, the calamity situation will imply some more restrictive measures regarding the opening hours of commercial establishments, restaurants, and bars; at the level of cultural or political activities with a maximum capacity that cannot exceed 150 people […] Both public and private parties are banned. Only intra-family parties are allowed.”  https://web.archive.org/web/20210502114936/https://expressodasilhas.cv/pais/2021/04/30/covid-19-governo-declara-estado-de-calamidade/74569

* Schools were closed throughout the country by march 15, 2020  * The government announced a new policy under which schools can reopen starting from Oct 29 2020 ( Oct 9 2013 Ethiopian calendar)  * Grade 8 and 12 students restarted school earlier because they were supposed to take national exams by mid 2020. Considering that they need to take exams before they transfer to the next grade, they were started in class before the others. After that schools were reopening slowly throughout the country. A through assessment and supervision was done on each school by the government before they were allowed to reopen.  * However, many students were not back to school by the time schools were functioning in the country partly accounting to the country's low socioeconomic status and partly due to parents hesitance to send their kids back to school so ministry of education launched a get back to school campaign  * currently all the schools are open and teach students under guidelines provided by the ministry of education( couldn't find a link for the current guidelinehttps://web.archive.org/web/20210507060637/https://www.facebook.com/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.facebook.com%2Ffdremoe%2Fposts%2F2927308790705694  https://web.archive.org/web/20210507060911/https://www.facebook.com/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.facebook.com%2Ffdremoe%2Fposts%2F2924619784307928    Please refer to previous notes to get a detailed information on school closure and reopening in the country

Is a curfew in place?  Yes  Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel?  Yes  Land borders between Guinea and Senegal, Guinea Bissau, Côte d’Ivoire, and Libera are open.  https://archive.vn/j3BSx#selection-2331.0-2347.91

The government of Guinea has implemented enhanced screening and quarantine measures to reduce the spread of COVID-19. All arriving and departing travellers must present the results of a negative PCR or antigen COVID-19 test. Masks are always required in the airport and on airplanes. Arriving passengers: testing must be completed no more than 72 hours prior to arrival in Guinea or the traveller will be tested upon arrival and be required to quarantine for 14 days. Arriving passengers with symptoms or who test positive for COVID-19 will be sent to a designated treatment centre until two negative tests are completed.   https://archive.vn/PkWOO

Are health screening procedures in place at airports and other ports of entry?  Yes   Arriving passengers:  testing must be completed no more than 72 hours prior to arrival in Guinea or the traveler will be tested upon arrival and be required to quarantine for 14 days.  Arriving passengers with proof of a negative test within the 72 hours prior to arrival will not undergo any additional testing or quarantine in Guinea.  Arriving passengers with symptoms or who test positive for COVID-19 will be sent to a designated treatment center until two negative tests are completed.  https://archive.vn/j3BSx

Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in Kenya Yes  PCR testing is widely available.  We expect antigen tests to be increasingly available during 2021.  If so, are test results reliably available within 72 hours? Yes  Turnaround times vary outside of major metropolitan cities, and it will be important to confirm the turnaround time with each lab.  Testing is available at the country’s major hospitals (Aga Khan Hospital, Nairobi Hospital, Kenyatta National Hospital) and private laboratories (Lancet laboratories, Meditest diagnostics).  The charge for the test is approximately USD 100 (KES 10,000) at private health facilities and USD 50 (KES 5,000) at government hospitals.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210511084133/https://ke.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Daily counts of cases are published, and contact tracing policies are in force.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210511090303/https://medical.unon.org/node/138  https://web.archive.org/web/20210511085840/https://www.health.go.ke/

Mandatory wearing of masks in public remains in effect. The government will not provide services to individuals not wearing a mask    https://web.archive.org/web/20210511084133/https://ke.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/    The Government of Kenya has directed that face masks must be worn in public places, except when dining, or when adhering to social distancing in hotels, gardens or on beaches.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210511083746/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/kenya/coronavirus

All land borders remain closed except for essential goods transporters, deportees, and those in special circumstances.   However, airline access is still permitted provided passenger provide a negative PCR test dated within 3 days.    On 26 April 2021, given concerns around new variants and surges in cases, the Malawian government imposed a ban on all but essential arrivals and travel, such as diplomatic and medical travel, of nationals or non-nationals that have resided in these countries for at least the previous seven days: India, Bangladesh, Pakistan, Brazil.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210502113108/https://mw.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

To support small and medium enterprises (SMEs), commercial banks and micro-finance institutions will be, on a case-by-case basis, restructuring SME loans and providing a moratorium on their debt service until end-June 2021. In addition, fees on contactless payment have been temporarily waived.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210502113719/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

To support small and medium enterprises (SMEs), commercial banks and micro-finance institutions will be, on a case-by-case basis, restructuring SME loans and providing a moratorium on their debt service until end-June 2021. Fees on mobile money transactions have been temporarily waived to encourage cashless transactions.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210517173957/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

Quarantine requirements  All new arrivals are expected to self-isolate at one location in the city of their arrival until the result of their second PCR test (which should be taken on day 7 of arrival) is known. If the second test is negative individuals can exit self-isolation from day 8 onwards. Anyone that has developed symptoms of coronavirus during their travel or later tests positive will be managed according to national guidelines for COVID-19 treatment. This may require quarantine at a government-monitored treatment centre.    See: http://web.archive.org/web/20210524152228/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/nigeria/entry-requirements

Public spaces and services  Gatherings of over 50 people outside of work places are prohibited, including all weddings, conferences and sporting events. Bars, restaurants other than in hotels, events and recreational centres are currently closed. Places of worship are permitted to hold services, subject to limitations set by state authorities. On 21 December, the Nigerian Government announced that schools will remain closed until at least 18 January 2021.    Visits to public institutions, including government buildings, have been limited.    Additional measures include a mandatory requirement to wear face masks in public spaces.    See: http://web.archive.org/web/20210510173033/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/nigeria/coronavirus

Despite these assurances, however, doubts persist which may further threaten the vaccination exercise, and possibly thwart the Nigeria’s authority target to vaccinate millions of eligible citizens within the next two years.    Aniette Patrick, journalist, says she thinks the issue of trust is a major challenge for most Nigerians because leadership has been a major challenge and people tend not to trust the system in place despite the campaigns and enlightenment.    “In Nigeria, I guess nonchalant attitude is one thing and lack of trust is another, people feel what the government is giving as vaccines may not be the same thing others are receiving, that is the common man understanding and I think that is the major factor,” she added.    Experts say vaccine hesitancy will not only threaten COVID-19 response but prevent Nigeria from achieving herd immunity.    The Public Relation officer, National Hospital, Abuja Tayo Haastrup reiterated that the Covid 19 response was first launched in National Hospital by the Federal government and on record, the first Doctor in Nigeria to take the vaccination in the center, is from the Hospital with two of their nurses.    Well within the first two weeks, we had a large turnout of people coming to take the vaccination and we created two venues for the vaccination. At the trauma center, we created some rooms there and we also we created another    “I am sure it was because of the awareness and media support within the period that encouraged people to come out for the vaccination but at today, the turnout is decreasing not as populated as it used to be when we started,” he said.    Chief consultant National Hospital, Abuja, Dr Rais Ibrahim, says as a healthcare provider, he has taken the vaccine so he can render his services to Nigerians adding that there is no pain and recommend everyone should get it.    ‘People are always resistant to change and something new but with time people will see the benefit of taking the vaccine so that you protect yourself and by extension protect your family,” he said.    A recent release by the National Primary Health Care Development Agency, NPHCDA, showed that only1, 043, 737 eligible Nigerians have so far been vaccinated with the first dose.    See: http://web.archive.org/web/20210510185706/https://www.africanews.com/2021/04/24/covid-19-nigerians-hesitant-to-get-vaccinated//

The FCT Primary Health Care Board (FPHCB) announced the end of the first round of Covid-19 vaccinations on the 14th of May, signalling that Nigeria had ended the first phase of the covid vaccinations which has so far helped reduced Nigeria’s infection rate to less than 50 cases per day, compared to over 500 during the peak of the second wave.    Last week, the federal government gave the green light for the commencement of the administration of the second dose of the Oxford-AstraZeneca Covid-19 vaccines on eligible Nigerians who had received their first shots.    On a visit to a Federal Hospital in Abuja where vaccinations are given, a nurse speaking anonymously disclosed to Nairametrics that the administration of the second dose of vaccinations is expected to commence sometime between the last week of May and the first week of June 2021.    Vaccination rate at the end of the first phase  At the end of the first phase on the 15th of May, 2021, Nigeria had used 89.2% of its first phase proportion, vaccinating 1,794,552 residents, according to the National Primary Health Care Development Agency.    Lagos State recorded the most vaccinations at 279,372, vaccinating 101% of its proportion, with the FCT vaccinating 96% of its proportion at 118,895.    Expectedly, Kogi State, which was one of the last states to resume vaccinations, has only vaccinated 14,401 residents, which is 66% of its first phase proportion.    See: http://web.archive.org/web/20210524171311/https://nairametrics.com/2021/05/17/covid-19-vaccines-where-nigeria-stands-today/

Arriving passengers at Kigali International airport must present a negative COVID-19 PCR test taken within 72 hours prior to first departure. Negative test certificates must include the term ‘PCR’. COVID-19 testing is not mandatory for accompanied children under 5 years. All passengers must complete the passenger locator form and upload the COVID-19 test certificate before heading to the airport. You should not use the NHS testing service to get a test in order to facilitate your travel to another country. You should arrange to take a private test.    All passengers will be screened upon entry.    If you are entering Rwanda you will need to take a PCR test on arrival. The testing costs 60 US dollars. You must wait 24 hours for the results in a designated transit hotel and respect all COVID-19 prevention measures. Test results can be checked on the Rwanda Biomedical Centre website. If your test result is positive, even if asymptomatic, while in Rwanda, you will be treated in line with Rwanda’s COVID-19 management guidelines until you have fully recovered, at your own cost.    If you are transiting Rwanda you may or may not need to take a test, depending on the length and type of transit. You should follow the Rwandan Government’s guidance for arriving into and departing from Rwanda and comply with health guidelines.    All passengers arriving from India are required to complete 7 days in mandatory quarantine upon arrival at a designated hotel at their own cost.    Land borders remain closed, except to returning Rwandan citizens and legal residents.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210210002839/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/rwanda/coronavirus

Tax deferral and relief measures include the following:(i) suspension of down payments on outstanding tax for amicable settlement, (ii) softening of enforcement for tax arrears collection, (iii) extension of the deadline for filing and paying CIT, (iv) fast-tracking of VAT refunds to SMEs, (v) CIT and PIT payments based on current year transactions, (vi) PIT exemption for private school teachers and tourism and hotel employees earning less than RWF 150,000/month, and (vi) VAT exemption for locally produced masks. The 30-day maturity period for the public health insurance scheme premium was removed to expedite access to medical services and the salaries of top civil servants for the month of April was redirected to welfare programs. The “Manufacture and Build to Recover Program” adopted end-2020 provides for VAT exemptions on construction materials and tax credits. The revised FY20/21 budget accommodates additional COVID-19-related spending, including to support the hard-hit transport sector in the form of fuel subsidies, ERF loans, and tax relief.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210425191611/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19#R

Minister of Health Dr Daniel Ngamije and and WHO Rwanda Representative Dr. Kasonde Mwinga received their first dose at the launch of the COVID-19 vaccination on 5 March. Within three weeks, over 348 000 people had received their first dose.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210408104316/https://www.afro.who.int/news/rolling-out-covid-19-vaccines-rwanda  Rwanda also received 102 960 doses of the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccines. India also supplied Rwanda with 50 000 doses of AstraZeneca vaccine doses. Vaccinations were carried out in public health facilities. Health workers – both from the public and private sectors – were vaccinated in public health facilities.       Additional vaccination posts were set up to ease access for vulnerable and high-risk groups. Traders were vaccinated in markets and elders brought to arenas in the capital Kigali.   Health workers are among the high-risk population groups being given priority vaccinations. The country has recorded over 22 000 COVID-19 cases.

The committee chaired by Governor Khaled Mustafa decided to limit the opening of universities in coordination with the state health emergency committee.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210510204928/https://www.dabangasudan.org/en/all-news/article/covid-19-in-sudan-state-of-emergency-as-cases-rise-in-north-kordofan

In the press conference at the premises of the Sudan News Agency (SUNA) yesterday, the Acting Minister of Education Tamadur El Tereifi confirmed that the basic school examinations will be held on time and that the secondary school examinations will also be held on the dates specified in advance despite the measures.    The Ministry of Higher Education and Scientific Research called on university administrations to inform them of the conditions that their universities are going through and whether they require an exception from the decision to suspend studies for a month.    In a letter addressed to university administrations, the ministry said that the circumstances that warrant the exception include the completion of the admission and registration procedures, performing the announced examinations, and conducting the necessary administrative work.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210521125406/https://www.dabangasudan.org/en/all-news/article/sudan-announces-several-new-measures-to-combat-covid-19

All travellers to Senegal over the age of two years must present an original COVID-19 test certificate showing a negative result. The test must occur within five days of entry into Senegal. The results must be from a PCR test (not a rapid test) and be issued by a laboratory approved for such testing or a recognized international health organization.  Travelers transiting Senegal must also show such proof if they will be present in Senegal more than 24 hours or wish to exit the airport.  Verification of testing compliance will be undertaken by the airline prior to departure. Passengers without a negative COVID-19 test may not be permitted to board.  All travellers to Senegal may also be required to complete a passenger location form for public health officials, in accordance with recommendations from the International Civil Aviation Organization. The form will be collected on arrival. The form is available for preview and download here.  The Government of Senegal has implemented restrictions that impact entry into Senegal for certain foreign nationals.  https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://sn.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

As of May 19, 2021, Senegal administered a total of 434,588 doses of vaccine against the coronavirus (COVID-19). The country started the vaccination campaign with the first 82 injections on February 23, 2021, using the Sinopharm vaccine. In March 2021, Senegal was among the first African countries to receive vaccine doses within the United Nations' COVAX initiative, which aims at providing vaccines to all countries in the world.   https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://sn.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/   https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://www.statista.com/statistics/1220438/total-number-of-covid-19-vaccination-doses-in-senegal/

The government of Sierra Leone has lifted the country's state of public health emergency and the associated 22:00-05:00 curfew as of late March. Nevertheless, a number of restrictions aimed at curbing the spread of COVID-19 remain in effect.  According to current directives, restaurants and bars must close on weekends, with clubs being closed completely. Sporting activities can be held without spectators. Religious services are subject to time restrictions. Facemasks are mandatory on public transportation and in public spaces.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210426074205/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/462621/sierra-leone-government-lifts-covid-19-state-of-public-health-emergency-and-curfew-as-of-late-march-update-19

Places of worship, churches and mosques have re-opened for worship but hand washing and social distancing is enforced. COVID-19 related restrictions in place in Seychelles were tightened May 04, 2021.  Under new measures, a curfew from 11:00 p.m. to 04:00 a.m. is in place until further notice.  Shops, bars, casinos, and other businesses are expected to operate shorter business hours.  Schools will be closed during this period.    https://archive.vn/BaTw5

http://web.archive.org/web/20210516140238/https://www.facebook.com/mohseychellesofficial/photos/a.666791056855362/1735744449960012/  1. Closure of all school up to Monday 24th May (Including post Secondary Institutions and Private Schools)

The re-introduced restrictions include earlier closure of shops, bars and casinos, a ban on commemoration gatherings, shows, group sporting activities and conferences. Travellers from India, Pakistan and Bangladesh are not permitted to travel to and enter Seychelles without proof of Covid-19 vaccination, which should be presented on application for Travel Authorisation. Vaccination certificates are subject to verification and approval of the Public Health Authority.  2. Travellers from Brazil are not permitted to travel to or enter Seychelles.

Visitors with physical presence in South Africa, India, Pakistan, Bangladesh, and Brazil within the 14 days preceding arrival are not permitted entry.   https://archive.vn/BaTw5#selection-2743.192-2743.343

es  http://web.archive.org/web/20210513194110/http://tourism.gov.sc/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Seychelles-Visitor-Travel-Advisory-6th-May-2021.pdf  Visitors who have been to Bangladesh, Brazil, India, Pakistan and South Africa within 14 days preceding arrival to Seychelles will NOT be authorised entry.

Within immediate effect, Seychelles is ready to welcome all visitors irrespective of their vaccination status on  the condition that they have a COVID-19 negative PCR test certificate that must be taken within 72 hours prior  to travel. However, visitors who have been in Bangladesh, Brazil, India, Pakistan and South Africa within the  14 days preceding arrival to Seychelles will unfortunately be restricted entry.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210524203329/http://tourism.gov.sc/wp-content/uploads/2021/05/Seychelles-Visitor-Travel-Advisory-21st-May-2021.pdf

https://archive.ph/Yv0cT#selection-20915.0-20915.463  In April 2020, the government has announced a measure - The Financial Assistance for Job Retention (FA4JR) program – to subsidize wages for companies facing distress caused by COVID-19. From July, Seychelles Employee Transition Scheme (SETS) was set up to facilitate the reskilling and placement in an economic activity of persons made redundant as a result of COVID-19. This program works alongside the wage subsidy to aid the transition to a post-COVID economy.

COVID-19 tests are available in Seychelles. All tests for the virus are conducted in the Public Health Lab of the Seychelles Hospital. Individuals seeking COVID-19 testing must contact the Seychelles Department of Health. Results are available within 48 hours. Cost of 2500 SCR (approximately $120 USD) must be paid in full by the patient.  https://archive.vn/QjHTL#selection-2783.0-2783.339

""""""In February 2021, the government, declared that it had no interest in taking part in vaccination programmes with the late President Magufuli urging the Ministry of Health, Community Development, Gender, Elderly and Children to conduct a robust evaluation before accepting the use of vaccines in the country. The government’s instruction was to maintain precaution and adhere to healthy practices including hand washing, eating healthy, exercising, protecting the elderly, and wearing face masks. In April 2021, under the new leadership of President Samia Suluhu Hassan, the government signalled a potential change in attitude towards COVID-19 prevention and response in the country by proposing the creation of a taskforce to reevaluate the United Republic of Tanzania’s approach to COVID-19."""" (Page 61).  https://web.archive.org/web/20210524023254/https://reliefweb.int/report/somalia/east-and-horn-africa-covid-19-strategic-response-and-recovery-plan-2021    https://web.archive.org/web/20210524014411/https://tz.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Adjusted alert level 1 is in place from 1 March 2021. All persons who are able to work from home must do so. However. persons will be permitted to perform any type of work outside the home. and to travel to and from work and for work purposes under Alert Level 1, subject to-  (a) strict compliance with health protocols and social distancing measures.  (b) the return to work being phased -in in order to put in place measures to make the workplace COVID-19 ready;  (c) the return to work being done in a manner that avoids and reduces risks of infection; and  (d) the work not being listed under the specific economic exclusions in this Table.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210510142403/https://www.gov.za/covid-19/about/coronavirus-covid-19-alert-level-1

A negative PCR test is required within 72 hours before departure to Zambia. Limited screening is in place at Lusaka airport which involves temperature checks as well as antigen tests if required. Symptomatic passengers may be asked to self-isolate for 14 days. No exit requirements are demanded by the Zambian government though airlines and destination countries may have their own health requirements.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210524163018/https://zm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-2/

Zambia on Friday reintroduced the COVID-19 test on arrival and the mandatory 14-day quarantine for travellers from 15 countries.    According to a joint statement from the Health Ministry and Public Health Institute in the capital Lusaka, the affected countries are South Africa, Tanzania, Kenya, Ethiopia, Egypt, Tunisia, India, Iran, Turkey, France, Germany, Russia, Italy, Brazil, and Argentina. The ministry said the list would be reviewed and updated regularly.    Otherwise international travel screening remains in place. A negative PCR test is required within 72 hours before departure to Zambia. Limited screening is in place at Lusaka airport which involves temperature checks as well as antigen tests if required. Symptomatic passengers may be asked to self-isolate for 14 days. No exit requirements are demanded by the Zambian government though airlines and destination countries may have their own health requirements.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210524163018/https://zm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-2/  http://web.archive.org/web/20210524165314/https://www.aa.com.tr/en/africa/zambia-reimposes-covid-19-restrictions-for-travelers/2249909

""A: AstraZeneca  Vaccination continues for key workers. The government is focusing on distributing the AstraZeneca vaccine through the COVAX facility, but the Chinese government is vaccinating Chinese nationals in Zambia with the Sinopharm vaccine. However the Sinopharm has not yet been approved for Zambian nationals. """"Zambia will consider adding the readily available Sinopharm to its basket of vaccines in line with Cabinet’s approval of the Zambia Vaccination Programme to ensure we have adequate vaccines for the eligible population in Zambia.""""    """"a cumulative 45,740 persons have been vaccinated against COVID-19 since 14th April 2021 when launched. This follows the vaccination of 2,593 with of both the AstraZeneca and Sinopharm vaccines (1,980 and 613 doses respectively) administered in the last 24 hours. The Sinopharm vaccine is being administered to Chinese Nationals Resident in Zambia by the Chinese government."""" ""A: AstraZeneca  Vaccination continues for key workers. The government is considering approving the Sinopharm vaccine, right now that continues to be administered by the Chinese government for Chinese nationals in Zambia.   May 12: """"Through our vaccine diplomacy pillar, we are excited to announce that the Chinese Government has pledged to provide Zambia with 100,000 doses of Sinopharm vaccine to go towards our vaccination programme. World health organisation recently approved the Sinopharm vaccine for emergency use in COVID-19. It is safe, efficacious and being used in over 100 countries.""""    May 15: """"Ladies and Gentlemen, in the last 24 hours, we administered an additional 7,417 doses of the AstraZeneca vaccine, bringing the cumulative number of vaccinated persons to 107,790 (of which 102,268 are AstraZeneca and 5,522 are Sinopharm doses administered). Health workers make up 21% of all those vaccinated with AstraZeneca, and this accounts for 35% of all health workers in the country and we will continue building on this.""""  https://web.archive.org/web/20210516232849/https://www.facebook.com/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.facebook.com%2Fmohzambia%2Fposts%2F1906336979540950    https://web.archive.org/web/20210515221722/https://www.facebook.com/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.facebook.com%2Fmohzambia%2Fposts%2F1908831159291532    https://web.archive.org/web/20210515223022/https://www.lusakatimes.com/2021/05/08/government-to-consider-chinese-covid-19-vaccine-2/  ""

No policy change. All schools reopened in a staggered manner as planned under health and safety guidelines. Exam classes returned on the 15th March with the rest of school years returning on the 22nd March.    Note: The June 2021 Zimsec public examinations for both O and A-Levels have been cancelled following disruptions caused by Covid-19 and the resulting lockdown with those who had wanted to sit in June now joining the large majority who are being prepared to sit in November.    The Zimbabwean government has also indicated it will take enforcement and implementation of covid health and safety rules in schools more carefully after several outbreaks.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210501130621/https://allafrica.com/stories/202103030501.html    http://web.archive.org/web/20210501130738/https://allafrica.com/stories/202104080184.html

No Change     Waiting for public transport:  Up to 50 people can gather to wait for public transport.  Previously up to 100 people could do so.  Places of business:  People can gather in shops, offices and other business places that are permitted to open.    Funerals:  Up to 30 people can attend a funeral;  there is no change here.    Religious services:  Up to 50 people can attend religious services at churches and other places of worship, so long as the premises are disinfected between services.  Previously religious services were prohibited.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210410112112/https://www.thezimbabwean.co/2021/03/public-health-lock-down-order-relaxation-of-lock-down/    Parliamentary committee hearings:  Up to 100 people can attend public hearings conducted by parliamentary committees.  These hearings were prohibited.

As of December 1, the Government of Zimbabwe requires all new arrivals to the country to present a negative COVID-19 PCR test result issued within the previous 48 hours. Persons without a test result or displaying COVID-19 symptoms may be denied entry into the country.     The Government of Zimbabwe requires returning residents to either have a negative COVID-19 PCR test result taken within the previous 48 hours or to get tested upon arrival and remain in a government holding facility while awaiting the results.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210501132006/https://zw.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-2/

As of December 1, the Government of Zimbabwe requires all new arrivals to the country to present a negative COVID-19 PCR test result issued within the previous 48 hours. Persons without a test result or displaying COVID-19 symptoms may be denied entry into the country.     The Government of Zimbabwe requires returning residents to either have a negative COVID-19 PCR test result taken within the previous 48 hours or to get tested upon arrival and remain in a government holding facility while awaiting the results.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210509135103/https://zw.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-2/

Non-residents entering Zimbabwe must possess a negative COVID-19 test result certificate, issued no more than 48 hours before their departure to Zimbabwe. Those who arrive in Zimbabwe without a negative PCR test certificate are required to quarantine at a designated hotel at their own expense. Those arriving with a negative PCR test certificate shall self-quarantine for 10 days from their date of arrival in Zimbabwe.    Returning citizens or residents of Zimbabwe who do not have a valid negative PCR test certificate on arrival are required to quarantine for 10 days at a designated hotel or other designated place of quarantine at their own expense and will only be released after a negative COVID-19 test result. Returning residents or citizens of Zimbabwe with proof of a negative PCR test certificate can self-quarantine at home for 10 days.    Enforcement of quarantine may vary.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210517093644/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/zimbabwe

Those who arrive in Zimbabwe without a negative PCR test certificate are required to quarantine at a designated hotel at their own expense. Those arriving with a negative PCR test certificate shall self-quarantine for 10 days from their date of arrival in Zimbabwe.    Returning citizens or residents of Zimbabwe who do not have a valid negative PCR test certificate on arrival are required to quarantine for 10 days at a designated hotel or other designated place of quarantine at their own expense and will only be released after a negative COVID-19 test result. Returning residents or citizens of Zimbabwe with proof of a negative PCR test certificate can self-quarantine at home for 10 days.    Enforcement of quarantine may vary.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210523211941/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/zimbabwe

Zimbabwe has moved into the second phase of its COVID-19 vaccination programme.  It’s now targeting the elderly people with chronic conditions, and essential workers like the police, army and prison employees.    In the first phase of the vaccination rollout, healthcare workers were targeted.    The Sinovax, Sinopharm, and Covaxin vaccines are being administered.    Note: The Zimbabwean government is targeting broad mass vaccination in Victoria Falls in an attempt to reopen the area to the tourism industry. This includes all adults aged between 18-65 from 29th March.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210501132006/https://zw.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-2/    http://web.archive.org/web/20210501135015/https://www.timeslive.co.za/news/africa/2021-03-23-zimbabwes-entire-tourist-town-of-victoria-falls-to-get-covid-19-vaccination/    http://web.archive.org/web/20210501135133/https://www.enca.com/news/zimbabwe-moves-second-phase-vaccination-programme

Sinopharm’s?BBIBP-CorV, Sinovac’sCoronaVac,?and Bharat Biotech’s COVAXIN have been made generally available.    It appears that these vaccines are no longer subject to group specification. However, supply issues and vaccine hesitancy have been raised as the biggest issues. The Zimbabwean Government is reported to be considering mandatory vaccination.    Note: The Zimbabwean government is targeting broad mass vaccination in Victoria Falls in an attempt to reopen the area to the tourism industry. This includes all adults aged between 18-65 from 29th March. Over 77% of the eligible Victoria Falls population has now been vaccinated.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210517094620/https://zw.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-2/    http://web.archive.org/web/20210517103929/https://www.newsday.co.zw/2021/05/poor-communication-behind-vaccine-hesitancy/

However, supply issues and vaccine hesitancy have been raised as the biggest issues. The Zimbabwean Government is reported to be considering mandatory vaccination.    Note: The Zimbabwean government is targeting broad mass vaccination in Victoria Falls in an attempt to reopen the area to the tourism industry. This includes all adults aged between 18-65 from 29th March.
